pageContext.description:
The composition is dominated by the standing figure of a young woman (Venus) before a dark bush. She is naked except for a wisp of transparent gauze that she stretches across her midriff, a necklace (a simple band with a single pearl drop), and a beret-like hat with three short plumes. She is seen from the left; her head inclined downwards and to the proper right; her eyes looking at the viewer; her right hand raised, her left by her left thigh. To the left, the naked figure of a winged infant (Cupid), holds up a honeycomb to Venus, to whom he looks up; his body is dotted with bees. To the right, the recumbent head and forelegs of a deer. Latin quatrain in a simple rectangular cartouche upper left corner
[http://www.vads.ac.uk/large.php?uid=87529](accessed 22.10.2014)

pageContext.provenance:
- Sir Thomas Gibson Carmichael, Bt, Castle Craig, Scotland, by 1901
- Sir Thomas Gibson Carmichael sale, Christie's, London, 13 May 1902, lot 267
- bought by 'Laurie' [? Lawrie & Co.], £57.15s., probably for Sir William Burrell (1861-1958), 8 Great Western Terrace, Glasgow.
- Given by Sir William and Lady Burrell 1944.
[Burrell collection, revised 2015]
